questions.text: A 40 year old man came with blurred vision since morning. He also described mild headache . IOP was 60 mmHg, AC shows minimum cells. What can be the correct statement regarding his diagnosis
questions.solution:
This is a case of Posner Schlossmann syndrome.

Atypical uveitis with minimal inflammation. Very high IOP not correlating with inflammation

Seen in young adults , idiopathic .

Trabeculitis leads to inflammation and high IOP

questions.text: A patient came with a history of trauma near eye. He also reports the vision is dropped since then. You have examined the patient and this was the picture. Vision is just FCCF and IOP is 40 mmHg. He is also a known case of sickle cell anaemia. Which drug would be best avoided in him
questions.solution:
• This is a case of hyphema after trauma. Collection of blood in AC.
  • Avoid oral carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, especially acetazolamide (eg, Diamox), in patients with sickle cell trait or disease. These drugs tend to increase sickling of erythrocytes and worsen the situation

questions.text: A female presented with a sudden painless loss of vision. She has no history of DM/ hypertension. On examination direct and consensual light reflex are normal. Retina also shows no changes but her VEP is subnormal. What is your provisional diagnosis
questions.solution:
loss of vision without any ophthalmological causes and with normal pupillary light reflexes due to bilateral lesions of the striate cortex in the occipital lobes

  • A complete loss of visual sensation and of vision
  • Preservation/sparing of the abilities to perceive light and/or moving, but not static objects Riddoch syndrome
  • Denial of visual loss Anton Babinski syndrome
  • Visual hallucinations
  • Macular sparing, in which vision in the fovea is spared from the blindness

questions.text:
7 year old baby was taken by mother to OPD with complaints of leucocoria since few months. Retina showed this picture.

Most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Coat's disease : Coats disease is a telangiectatic neovascular disease of the retina of unknown etiology that frequently affects unilateral eyes of young males.
  • Divided in three groups
  • Group I demonstrated massive subretinal exudate alone,
  • group II consisted of eyes with massive subretinal exudate, intra and subretinal hemorrhage, and retinal vascular dilatations, and
  • group III included eyes with subretinal exudate and retinal arteriovenous malformations
  • The major clinical significance of Coats Disease is to differentiate it from Retinoblastoma since both appear with leukocoria, but calcium seen in CT or ultrasound excludes Coats in favor of Retinoblastoma.

questions.text: A girl came to OPD after LASIK. What would be her reading on applanation as compared to pre op reading
questions.solution:
As we have thinning of cornea after LASIK surgery, we expect the value which we calculate on tonometer will be less than expected.

As Goldman applanation tonometer is calliberated for CCT of 520 microns

Central corneal thickness is correlated with intraocular pressure. A thick cornea leads to an overestimation of IOP while thin cornea leads to an underestimation of IOP.

questions.text: A 30 year old female came with sudden history of LE loss of vision since morning. She describes a lot of pain in eye and headache. She is unable to open the eye also comfortably. On examination Anterior Segment examination is normal. Retina IOP all are normal. She is able to approximate her finger with right eye closed but not with left eye closed. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Functional Visual Loss (FVL) is a decrease in visual acuity and/or visual field not caused by any organic lesion. It is therefore also called "nonorganic visual loss" (NOVL).
  • This entity is considered within the spectrum of "conversion disorder", malingering, somatic symptom disorder, and "factitious disorder".

Diplopia is both on looking up and down
The blow is usually by an object slightly smaller or same size of orbital aperture.

questions.text: What is not true about orbital blow out fracture
questions.solution: The blow is usually by an object slightly larger than orbital aperture

choices.text: Indirect ophthalmoscopy to see retinal changes should be done
The earliest sign for his condition is conjunctival xerosis
Vitamin A 1 lac IU should be given to him stat

questions.text: An 8year old boy living in a remote village, presented with his mother in OPD with difficulty in vision during evening hours as explained by mother as frequent falls during his playing hours in evening. On examination his vision was 6/6 in both eyes. But anterior segment shows this picture. He appeared to be malnourished also. What is not correct in this regard
questions.solution:
This is a picture showing conjunctival xerosis in xerophthalmia

As this child is more than 1 year, the prescribed dosage of vitamin A is 2 lack IU orally or 1 lack IU IM

questions.text: A woman presents to you complaining of a red, watering eye for the past two days with stinging. Her vision has dropped slightly to 20/30. She has a history of diabetes and taking drops for glaucoma, but is otherwise healthy. The most likely cause of her redness is
questions.solution: None other condition presents like this. There is very mild blurred vision but not actual decrease in vision. So conjunctivitis is the most likely cause

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't require treatment
questions.solution:
Indications of treatment in DR

  1. PDR
  2. Any NPDR with CME

For NPDR alone strict DM control and frequent follow ups are required

choices.text: Deflection of veins at arteriovenous crossing
Tapering of veins on the either side of the crossings

questions.text: Gunn sign is
questions.solution:
AV crossing changes in hypertensive retinopathy

AV crossing changes occur when a thickened arteriole crosses over a venule and subsequently compresses it as the vessels share a common adventitious sheath

  • Salus's sign: Deflection of retinal vein as it crosses the arteriole.
  • Gunn's sign: Tapering of the retinal vein on either side of the AV crossing.
  • Bonnet's sign: Banking of the retinal vein distal to the AV crossing.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of seeing "spots" floating around in her right eye. Today, she notes streaks of light in the same eye accompanied by a "shadow" in her vision which she describes as curtain that moves when looking up and down. Her medical history is significant for migraine headaches; however, she has never had such visual symptoms with her headaches. There is a history of using glasses also since 20 years . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: This is a case of myopia with rhegmatogenous retinal detachment

questions.text: A patient comes to you with flashes and floaters. In retina a lesion was seen. Treatment of this condition
questions.solution: This is a lattice degeneration seen in high myopia, we can laser the area by photocoagulation so that the tear doesn't develop and RRD doesn't occur

choices.text: All of the above is equally responsible.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy came with difficulty in copying from blackboard on school. When he visited you the vision was found to be 6/24. what is the most common cause of such a problem
questions.solution: • The most common cause of myopia is increased axial length . This is axial myopia

questions.text:
A 60 year old female came with decreased vision of both eye. On examination vision is 6/24 and 6,18. Anterior segment is normal with IOP of 18 mmHg in BE. There is a history of chronic arthritis since last 20 years. The drug history is not available. Fundus shows this picture.

What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
• CQ and HCQ bind to melanin in RPE and cause damage to cones in the macula. They inhibit RPE phagocytosis function causing accumulation of shed photoreceptors in the outer segment
  • Usually not reversible.
  • May lead to permanent damage
  • Other manifestations of CQ toxicity
  • whorl deposits
  • Macular pigmentation
  • PSC
  • Hudson stahli line

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presents with trauma on his head. He is complaining of double vision on looking down. On examination, tilting head towards R side worsens double vision. What muscle has been paralyzed.
questions.solution: R SO paralysed as tilting head on same side increase separation of images. As this eye not able to intort as compensation for head tilt.

questions.text: A 55 year old diabetic hypertensive patient came with decrease in vision, nausea headache and vomiting since two days. He also reports similar episodes like this since many months. His pupil is mid dilated and cornea is hazy. IOP is 32mm Hg. Retinal examination also showed minimal macular edema. He told history of some retinal investigations and procedure done in past. What is the best drug to be given for his IOP reduction
questions.solution: This is a diabetic macular edema with high IOP due an attack of angle closure. Also, there is CME so to control IOP latanoprost, pilocarpine and epinephrine all are avoided as they all are pro inflammatory

questions.text: A patient having prescription of glasses as +1 DC at 90Deg. Which type of astigmatism it is
questions.solution: As we have only cylinder in this prescription it is simple astigmatism

So optic atrophy after retinal disorders are consecutive OA

questions.solution:
Maddox rod has multiple red cylinders arranged parallel in form of disc which converts a point source of light in a red line perpendicular to its axis.

So basically it breaks fusion when it is kept in front of one eye

choices.text: Excimer laser is used after femtolaser
Not suitable for very high myopia
Visual outcome comparable to other refractive surgeries

questions.text: What is not true about this surgery
questions.solution:
This is a picture of Small incision lenticule extraction (SMILE). It is a relatively new refractive procedure designed to treat refractive errors such as myopia, hyperopia, presbyopia, and astigmatism.

The procedure involves using a femtosecond laser to create a corneal lenticule which is extracted whole through a small incision without the use of an excimer laser.

Excimer laser is used for stromal thinning in cases of LASIK , not smile surgery Visual outcome is similar to laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK)

questions.text: A 20 year old patient came with mild ptosis which was there since birth in him for a routine check up in your OPD. You found meiosis also on the same eye. What finding will let you diagnose a case of congenital horner syndrome in this patient
questions.solution:
Horner's syndrome

  • HI : heterochromia iridium ( seen only in chronic / congenital cases )
  • P : ptosis ( mild)
  • A : anhidrosis
  • M : meiosis
  • E : enophthalmos
  • L : Loss of ciliospinal reflex
  • A : anisocoria

questions.text: Identify the instrument
questions.solution:
A phoropter is an instrument comprised of cylinders, prisms, and lenses that measures the eye's refractive error to help determine and eye prescription.

  • The main advantages of phoropters are: A quicker refraction: As the lenses are all contained within the phoropter, it is much quicker to change lens powers for both retinoscopy and subjective refraction than with a trial frame. This may also provide less back strain for the examiner.

questions.text: A young patient presents to you for cosmetic squint surgery. What is you diagnosis after examination of the patient
questions.solution:
Vertically incomitant pattern strabismus is used to describe the type of strabismus wherein the amount of horizontal deviation changes during the excursion of the eye from upgaze to downgaze.

V-pattern: When the eye converges as the eye moves from up to downgaze, a V-pattern is present.

In V-pattern esotropia, the deviation is more in downgaze than in upgaze, and in V-pattern exotropia the deviation is more in upgaze than in downgaze. This is the most common type of pattern in strabismus.

The V-pattern is considered to be significant if the difference in horizontal deviation between the 2 gazes is ≥ 15 prism diopters.

A-pattern: When the eye converges as the eye moves from down to upgaze, it is termed as an A-pattern. Therefore in an A-pattern esotropia, the deviation is more in upgaze than in downgaze , and in an A-pattern exotropia the deviation is more in downgaze than in upgaze.

The A-pattern is considered significant if the difference in horizontal deviation between the 2 gazes is ≥ 10 prism diopters.

questions.text: What is best for treatment for headache. Chronic pain in eye for a 50 year old man working with laptop almost 7 hours a day
questions.solution:
• Simply this patient has presbyopia
  • Give him near vision add, and his headache should get better

questions.text: A 20 year male came to you with complaint of discomfort by his glasses and frequent change in number. You observe a sign in him when he is asked to look down which is shown in the picture . All are other signs can be expected in him except
questions.solution:
• Joffroy sign: absent wrinkling of the forehead when a patient with Graves Ophthalmopathy looks up with the head bent forwards.
  • The case here is about keratoconus
  • The rest of the signs are seen in keratoconus
  • The pic given is of munson sign - notching of lower lid on looking down

questions.text: A 70 year old lady presented with sudden painless loss of vision in RE since morning. She also describes this loss of vision as only superior field is disturbed and she is not able to see my face properly. There is also scalp tenderness and headache. Her BP is 130/80 mmHg. Retina shows a pale disc. What is the provisional diagnosis
questions.solution:
• This is case of a old lady presenting with AION due to GCA (arteritic type) - scalp tenderness and headache
  • The old lady has a superior field defect and a pale disc which is again suggestive of AION

questions.text: A male patient with a history of hypermature cataract presents with a 2 day history of ciliary congestion, photophobia, blurring of vision and on examination has a deep anterior chamber in the right eye. The left eye is normal the diagnosis is
questions.solution:
phacolytic glaucoma : it is secondary open glaucoma seen in HMSC stage . Deep AC is the characteristic sign .

Seen in Hypermature morgagnian cataract : Cortex liquifies and the nucleus settles down giving a BAG of MILK appearance.

Micro leaks develops in the capsule from which lens proteins leak out and get deposited in angle→ decreased drainage of aqueous →secondary open angle glaucoma - phacolytic glaucoma

questions.text: What is initial modality of treatment for this child after examination and refractive error correction
questions.solution: someone with an esotropia, or inward deviation of an eye, can benefit from 'base out' prism in their glasses. This would move the image in toward their nose, where their fovea naturally lies.

questions.text: What will be the angle subtended by the snellen's optotype of second line when viewed from a distance of 6 mtr
questions.solution:
• MAR is inverse of visual acuity
  • for 6/60 vision what is MAR = 10 min of arc ( 60/6)
  • for vision 6/60 angle subtended is - who is at 6 mtr = 50 min
  • if vision is 6/36 - angle subtended at 6 mtr
  • 36 /6 x 5 = 30 min

questions.solution: This is a picture of peripheral iridomy. It is done by Nd YAG A hole is created as an alternative route if drainage of aqueous in mid peripheral part of iris

questions.text: Spherical equivalent of -4 / + 1 DC at 90 degree
questions.solution:
1. Take half the value of the cylinder and
  2. Add it to the sphere power.

In other words, as a formula the spherical equivalent Spherical Equivalent = Sphere + (Cylinder)/2

questions.text: A 35 year old male comes to you with decrease in vision in BE. It is a painless decrease. His vision is 6/ 36 and 6/ 18 in RE and LE respectively. AC is clear, no cells, IOP is normal. He also describes there has been an accident in recent past with a head injury. On looking at SL picture what is the next question comes to your mind.
questions.solution: This SL picture is of snowflake cataract, seen in DM. so 1st question to patient would be of a history of ant metabolic disorder like DM

choices.text: Slit lamp bimicroscopy with 90 D lens

questions.text: Which investigation is best by which these two pathologies can be seen
questions.solution:
First is posterior subcapsular cataract and the second is subluxated lens. So they are seen by slit lamp and Distant direct ophthalmoscope.

Slit lamp bimicroscopy with 90 D lens is actually to see retina

questions.text: Fluorescein dye is used in all tests / procedures except
questions.solution: Check up of corneal curvature - Done by a keratometer

questions.text: What level of vision quantifies a patient to be labelled as economically blind?
questions.solution:
Economic - <6/60 - 3/60

Social - < 3/60 - 1/60

Manifest - <1/60 to PL

Absolute - no PL
